awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Radiation and Climate Gordon Research Conference and Seminar; Lewiston, Maine; July 22-28, 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the twelfth Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Radiation and Climate, to be held at Bates College in Lewiston, Maine, 23-28 July 2023. Additional support is provided for the sixth Gordon Research Seminar (GRS), convened just prior to the GRC. The GRS is a pre-conference meeting targeted specifically at students and early-career scientists, intended to provide an environment in which participants with comparable levels of experience and education can come together to discuss their current research and build networks for long-term collaboration. The theme of the GRC and GRS is "Theoretical and Observational Constraints on Climate System Behavior", including constraints derived from conservation principles and power law relationships.  Topics include constraints on precipitation from energy balance, emerging observational techniques, and constraints on climate system behavior due to radiative transfer in the water vapor continuum.

The GRC and GRS have scientific broader impacts by serving as a venue for the exchange of results and ideas among researchers attempting to understand the radiative processes that govern weather and climate. The meeting is expected to be particularly advantageous for early-career scientists, as it is formulated to promote in-depth interactions among junior and senior scientists over the course of a week, in a conducive setting of manageable size with few distractions. The topics to be addressed are of societal interest given the key role of radiative effects in controlling and regulating climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Radiation and Climate were held at Bates College in Lewiston, Maine from July 23-28, 2023. The meeting covered a variety of scientific topics and the content presented was highly rated by participants. The Conference was well-attended with 129 participants. Scientists from academia represented 69% of the participants while attendees from government accounted for 18%, attendees from industry totaled 1% and those from academic/industrial accounted for 12%. The meeting attracted a strong mix of young investigators and senior scientists. Students and post-docs accounted for 59% of all attendees. Approximately 40% of the participants at the 2023 meeting were women. 

The Radiation and Climate GRC was a premier, international scientific conference focused on advancing the frontiers of science through the presentation of cutting-edge and unpublished research, prioritizing time for discussion after each talk and fostering informal interactions among scientists of all career stages. The conference program theme was “Theoretical and Observational Constraints on Climate System Behavior” and included a diverse range of speakers and discussion leaders from institutions and organizations worldwide, concentrating on the latest developments in the field. 

The meeting discussed a range of fundamental drivers of the underlying coherence within the climate system and explored new avenues to leverage this coherence to increase understanding of climate system behavior and improve modeling and predictive capabilities. The session topics (https://www.grc.org/radiation-and-climate-conference/2023/) were of high interest to the community and represent areas where fundamental progress can be made, and the speakers are world leading experts: importantly, a mix of more senior and junior leaders. 

Several outcomes key project outcomes and findings resulted from the conference. First, as in the spirit of a Gordon Research Conference, a key outcome was the development of new relationships between junior and senior scientists. These new relationships resulted from the networking opportunities and interactive poster sessions that are embedded within the GRC and GRS program. Secondly, several important research areas were highlighted as part of the presentations and discussion as needing attention including the establishing of a Global Climate Observing System, connecting global kilometer scale modeling efforts to inform climate model development, and the need to further develop machine learning capabilities within climate science. 

Overall, the feedback collected from the meeting was extremely positive. Evaluations included numerous positive remarks regarding the networking opportunities, the quality of the discussion, the respectful and collegial environment, the interactive and engaging poster sessions as well as the cutting-edge scientific content.
